+Windows Usage
+==========================
+
+Building from source
+--------------------
+
+Include optional components
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+There're two supported components for Windows PyTorch:
+MKL and MAGMA. Here are the steps to build with them.
+
+.. code-block:: bat
+
+    REM Make sure you has 7z and curl installed.
+
+    REM Download MKL files
+    curl https://s3.amazonaws.com/ossci-windows/mkl_2018.2.185.7z -k -O
+    7z x -aoa mkl_2018.2.185.7z -omkl
+
+    REM Download MAGMA diles
+    REM cuda90/cuda91 is also available in the following line.
+    set CUDA_PREFIX=cuda80 
+    curl -k https://s3.amazonaws.com/ossci-windows/magma_%CUDA_PREFIX%_release_mkl_2018.2.185.7z -o magma.7z
+    7z x -aoa magma.7z -omagma
+    
+    REM Setting essential environment variables
+    set "CMAKE_INCLUDE_PATH=%cd%\\mkl\\include"
+    set "LIB=%cd%\\mkl\\lib;%LIB%"
+    set "MAGMA_HOME=%cd%\\magma"
+
+Speeding CUDA build for Windows
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Visual Studio doesn't support parallel custom task currently.
+As an alternative, we can use ``Ninja`` to parallelize CUDA
+build tasks. It can used by typing only a few lines of code.
+
+.. code-block:: bat
+    
+    REM Let's install ninja first.
+    pip install ninja
+
+    REM Set it as the cmake generator
+    set CMAKE_GENERATOR=Ninja
+
+
+One key install script
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+You can take a look at the script `here
+<https://github.com/peterjc123/pytorch-scripts>`_. 
+It will lead the way for you.
body: Actually the build steps in README.md are sufficient to build. But it needs some manual configuration to get better, like detecting and including the optional components(MKL, MAGMA, Ninja and etc.), and doing some checks for the missing dependency. (MSVC, Python). Some users may not read the docs very carefully, so providing them an additional helper script may be a good idea.
